title: Secure, Role-Driven Service Operations
excerpt: Role-driven case management with confidential access and executive visibility across regulatory, pricing, complaints, and vendor compliance.

hero.title: Service operations that are fast, clear, and secure
hero.subhead: Digitized casework for regulatory, pricing, complaints, and vendor compliance with the right people seeing the right data at the right time.

sections.quote: Exactly what we needed: secure access, clear ownership, and reporting that reflects reality.

sections.title: Manual, ambiguous processes created risk across regulatory, pricing, complaints, and vendor compliance.

sections.body: What success looked like for Virginia Dare

items.title: Define service roles & access
items.body: Clarify responsibilities and permissions for regulatory, pricing, complaints, vendor compliance, and sales.

items.title: Improve process efficiency
items.body: Guided, role-based workflows aligned to best practices; less swivel-chair work.

items.title: Enable reporting without overexposure
items.body: Managers and executives see real-time metrics without unnecessary data access.

sections.title: What we built
sections.bodyBefore: Green Irony implemented secure, role-driven service operations on Salesforce Service Cloud.

bullets.body: Requirements workshops; mapped user personas to platform capabilities.
Responsibility matrices for regulatory agents, pricing agents, complaint managers, sales, and executives—including confidential edge cases.
Granular access protocols by case type; confidential complaints limited to designated managers.
Role-driven case lifecycles (intake → assignment → work → reporting) plus executive dashboards and account-level visibility.

sections.title: Outcome Highlights
sections.body: With role-driven workflows and granular access on Service Cloud, Virginia Dare achieved:
items: Clear division of duties and auditable access for sensitive data.
Faster resolution and fewer errors via guided, role-based workflows.
Real-time visibility for managers and executives—without exposing restricted information.
